Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2010 03:59PM Rosemary349 wrote: Hi Everyone!  Thanks for your replies.  I did have the biopsy.  I spoke to a friend who is a naturopath today and she said eat lots and lots of tumeric, it blocks tumour growth.  I checked it out on the internet and here's an interesting link:  http://www.womens-health-questions.com/benefitsofturmeric.html  Just thought i'd share.  I have a question.....is it normal after a biopsy to be more aware of swelling on the breast than before?  I was not really aware of any swellling before but now i am.  Is that just the injury that has taken place?  Also i'm aware of discomfort and i wasn't before - is this all a result of the biopsy?  I will come back here at the weekend, it's a bit of a hectic week right now and not logging on til late.  :-)
Posts.Title: Scared and Alone Rosemary349 Rosemary349

Posts.Title: Scared and Alone Rosemary349 Rosemary349

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2010 02:30PM Rosemary349 wrote: Thanks Horsedoc  I typed out a long response to you yesterday but i wasn't allowed to post!  I've just read that not only tumeric but also black pepper is a breast cancer preventer......now the interesting thing is that i often ate with my parents and my dad always had black pepper in his house, so i always used it....when he died last september, mum ran out of pepper and didn't get any more.  Since i spent a number of months eating with her, i wasn't getting any pepper.  Interesting that that was when the itching started in my nipple.  I know i might be making connections where there aren't any - but it is interesting.  That was the one change in my diet... I have to go in for my results on monday, i don't know how i'm going to cope.  I don't want my mum to come with me, this is all way above her head.  None of my friends have offered.....i'm thinking whatever just go in alone.....how did anyone else cope with this? Also, I'm now quite aware of the 'lump' since the biopsy.  There is still discomfort, there wasn't before.  Does this mean that i'm just feeling the injury of the biopsy or does it mean there really is a disease there?  Obviously at this stage i don't know the results and i'm guessing....hoping the discomfort is due to the biopsy injury
Posts.Title: Scared and Alone Rosemary349 Rosemary349

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2010 03:56PM Rosemary349 wrote: Although it's very slight, there's also an itchiness around the area of the biopsy.  It's not intense or anything.  Does anyone know is that just where the body is trying to heal from the biopsy?  Or should i worry?

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2010 02:19PM Rosemary349 wrote: Thanks guys I'm thinking, how we react to things can determine how our bodies react to it.  Cancer is a word.  It's one word, and has many many different meanings....throw in an individual's own unique constitution into that and the outcomes are not known and yet so many of us (not us personally but society - through the media) fear it.  Wayne Dyer referred to his own cancer as 'just another life force.'  He said when we struggle against something we weaken ourselves.  It may be true.  He hopes that his spiritual approach will enable him to live in harmony with it.  Anyway, not pushing that stuff at all, just something i read in a magazine.....You guys have been wonderful through all this.
Posts.Title: Scared and Alone Rosemary349 Rosemary349

I think from what they saw they didn't want to reassure me in anyway.  it would be great to hear from anyone who got a similar reaction from the doctors  and then it turned out to be benign.... I know that won't change anything for me, what will be will be.....but it might help me get through the wait for the biopsy results....  thanks again, i don't have children, i am 39, I'm not married....i've got friends and a mum (who's in a state about having just lost her husband)...  thanks for listening  :-)

Posts.Content: Rosemary349 wrote: Hi there I'm so scared and i feel so alone.  I lost my father suddenly about 6 months ago and now i've just had a mammogram and ultrasound and the doctors said it looks like cancer.  They can't see any in the lymph nodes.  I have to have a biopsy tomorrow.  I asked what the chances were of it being cancer and the doctor said 90% but needs to know what type, so needs to do the biopsy....  All this started from an itchy nipple that has actually cleared itself, but there is a mass in there...  I have no one in my life, a few friends on the end of a phone and i am so scared.  I hate anything medical and have a phobia of vomiting, passing out or anything like that.    I'm just so scared, can anyone help? Posts.Title: Scared and Alone Rosemary349 Rosemary349

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2010 05:12PM Rosemary349 wrote: Linda  thankyou!!!!!  :-) Is there any chance at all that the biopsy could come back benign?  I mean he said there was a 90% chance of cancer form what they saw on the scan.....but that the physical examination was fairly good.  Also the itching in my nipple has stopped since i've stopped wearing (don't laugh!) thermal underwear (it's been really cold here in england!).....  So there's a 10% chance it's benign, but that's not good.......also they really want to rush this biopsy.  They seem sure.  I read the notes when they weren't looking and i saw 'strongly suspicious of carcinoma.' Should i even be thinking they might be benign?  I'm preparing myself for the fact that the result won't be.... thanks for your support!  I feel less alone already  :-)
Posts.Title: Scared and Alone Rosemary349 Rosemary349

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2010 05:57PM Rosemary349 wrote: Another thing i've realised is that the doctor was quoting general stats to me.....10% of these investigations are false positives....90% are accurate.  I thought he was applying 90% to my individual scan, ie from what he had seen on the picture....but it is becoming clear he was quoting general stats on this.  There is a 90% chance of it being accurate and 10% that it's not - and the biopsy will confirm.  So perhaps he was not looking at me in any particular way as being at any greater risk than those stats would say that i am.....but at the time i thought he was.  I though the 90% applied to my individual case. Now i am also reading that 70 to 80 percent of all positive mammograms do not, upon biopsy, show any presence of cancer.  This would seem to contradict what the doctor said above. thoughts?
Posts.Title: Scared and Alone Rosemary349 Rosemary349

They want to take the radial scar out and they said they routinely give it another check over but they are happy for me to go home and be pleased the result is benign. Going to my mum's for dinner, she's been worried, so i will chat later

Posts.Title: Check out Dr Jorge Fleschas Rosemary349 ananda8

Posts.Content: Rosemary349 wrote: Hi ladies I've just heard a really compelling interview with Dr Jorge Fleschas about the need for iodine and how lack of it causes all kinds of breast disease.  I've always avoided iodine because i take thyroid medication, but it is worth listening to him.    Japanese women eat 13.8 mg  of iodine daily.  They have the lowest rates of breast cancer (and heart disease) in the world.  The average person in the US eats only micrograms of iodine per day, 138 mcgs.  I know it's controversial, but i think it's worth a listen.  50% of people in the US get heart disease eventually, only 5% of Japanese do.  They live on fish and seaweed.    I think we need to keep an open mind but it wouldn be foolish not to share this info.  What do you think? Anyway, just sharing what i've read, hope this is helpful and not stressful to you.  :-)  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Check out Dr Jorge Fleschas Rosemary349 ananda8
